text:
WORDS SIMILAR IN MEANING (SYNONYMS)

What is a synonym?

A Synonym may be defined as a word that has the same meaning or the same general meaning as a particular word in the same Language or is in some applications a more or less satisfactory application of it. Thus, the synonym of a word can be an exact equivalent in meaning or should at least convey its meaning in one way or the other or should show in what sense it can best be used.

Context Clues

The Good news is that you can even predict accurately, the synonym of a word in a sentence even without knowing the accurate meaning of the word.  Understanding vocabulary, can be easily mastered using a tool always available to you; context. 

You can understand any new vocabulary term using only the context around it. By looking at the elements of a passage, an unknown vocabulary word reveals its meaning. 

Most English words are ambiguous, they have multiple meanings that vary in how much they overlap. Many words have multiple semantically-unrelated meanings.

Examples

Watch - a time piece

Watch - to look

Rose - a flower

Rose - past tense of rise

Others have multiple semantically-related senses 

Example 

twist an ankle

twist the truth

So, to determine the meaning of a word in a sentence you must relate it with the words before and after it in that particular sentence.

This is how the questions are framed - In each of questions 6-9, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase in italics.

 

Steps in Selecting Option Most Similar in Meaning

1. Always re-read the instruction at the top bar each time you enter a new question, most times due to the way the CBT platform is designed. Students normally assume they are still answering questions on options similar in meaning without knowing that they have entered antonyms. Be very careful.

2. Try to understand the central meaning of the given sentence as a whole.

2. Eliminate the obviously wrong answers like the options opposite in meaning to the underlined word.

3. Make a habit of reading all the options that are provided to you before answering the questions to be sure you are not fooled by nearly correct choices. 

4. Select an answer that is the most similar and in context to the underlined or italicised word.

We have discovered from research that people that do well in English mastered previous UNN PUTME Past questions and Jamb Questions. So, we advise you to memorise all the examples in this app. You can also go to the glossary and study the words there.

Examples

UNN PUME 2005/2006 (II)

1. Much of his chagrin, he did not win the race.

A. stupefaction. B. disappointment. C. shock. D. surprise

(B. Disappointment. Chagrin: a feeling of being frustrated or annoyed because of failure or disappointment)

 

2. Traditional rulers are not supposed to be involved in partisan politics.

A. dirty. B. party. C. modern. D. surprise

(B. Party. Partisan: a firm adherent to a party, faction, cause, or person; especially: one exhibiting blind, prejudiced, and unreasoning allegiance).

 

3. Mr. Adamu is a dominant partner in our business.

A. a prominent. B. an important. C. an outstanding. D. an influential

(B. an important. Dominant: more important, powerful, or successful than most or all others: most common)

 

4. The patient disregarded the advice of the doctor.

A. ignored. B. disobeyed. C. questioned. D. respected

(A. Ignored. Disregarded: to ignore (something) or treat (something) as unimportant). 

 

PUTME 2008/2009

5. Because more reliable evidence is needed to prosecute the case, it is now in abeyance.

A. court record. B. suspension. C. privacy. D. secret

(B. Suspension: temporary inactivity: suspension).

 

6. In the olden days. mothers of twins were never accepted as members of the society. They were simply _____.

A. banished. B. excommunicated. C. expelled. D. ostracized

D. Ostracized: to not allow (someone) to be included in a group: to exclude (someone) from a group Excommunicated: excluded from the rights of church membership).

 

PUME UNN 2009/2010

7. He lost his voice momentarily.

A. in a moment. B. in a split moment. C. for a brief period of time. D. without delay. E. instantly

(C. for a brief period of time).

 

8. In some parts of India, people are ostracized simply because of their ancestry.

A. abandoned. B. shut off from society. C. refused education. D. rendered unhappy. E. hated

(B. shut off from society).

 

PUME UNN 2010/2011

9. We consider the recent silver jubilee celebration in the state a very historic event.

A. important. B. memorable. C. ancient. D. critical

(B. Memorable)

 

10. The governor's address during his recent visit to our town was delivered extempore.

A. out-of-hand. B. timely. C. off-hand. D. expertly

(C. off-hand).

 

11. One of the candidates was handed over to the police for attending the interview with spurious credentials.

A. false. B. incomplete. C. unsigned. D. altered

(A. False).

 

12. There is a theory that postulates that all Nigerian languages derive from one source.

A. confirms. B. affirms. C. suggests. D. emphasizes

(C. Suggests).

 

13. The candidate was disqualified as a result of his irreverent behaviour.

A. shameful. B. disrespectful. C. careless. D. abnormal

(B. Disrespectful). 

 

PUME UNN 2011/2012 

14. The man's story gave Us an inkling of what we went through during the war.

A. a taste. B. a possible idea. C. a wrong notion. D. a suggestion

(B. a possible idea).

 

15. The statement credited to the honourable member is an aspersion on the reputation of my company.

A. a libel. B. a slander. C. a condemnation. D. an abuse

(B. A slander).

 

PUME UNN 2012/2013

16. We all praised the students' leaders for their intrepid stand during the crisis.

A. fearless. B. cheerful. C. reasonal. D. impressive

(A. Fearless)

 

17. There is a theory that postulates that all Nigerian languages. derive from one source.

A. confirms. B. affirms. C. suggests. D. emphasizes

(C. Suggests)

 

18. People strongly feel that Henry won at the election because he is silver-tongued.

A. slippery. B. eloquent. C. flippant. D. loquacious

(B. Eloquent). 

 

PUME UNN 2014/2015

19. Ngozi was of a permanent job.

A. regular. B. temporary. C. long-lasting. D. popular

(C. Long-lasting and indefinite). 

 

PUME UNN 2014/2015 (II)

20. Our aunt has expressed deep appreciation for Onyinye's invaluable assistance during the party.

A. immeasurable. B. praiseworthy. C. selfless. D. worthless

(A. Immeasurable).

 

21. Many world leaders have continued to condemn the South African Prime Minister for his truculent posture.

A. impetuous. B. impertinent. C. aggressive. D. impervious

(C. Aggressive).

 

PUME UNN 2015/2016

22. Ugo has often been described as belligerent.

A. attractive. B. combative. C. innocent. D. patient

(B. Combative: fighting a war: engaged in a war).

 

23. Mohammed does his work with so much ardour

A. enthusiasm. B. discouragement. C. knowledge. D. indifference

(A. Enthusiasm: Ardour means a strong feeling of love).

 

24. The policy has been espoused by the ruling party

A. rejected. B. outlined. C. supported. D. condemned

(C. Supported: Espoused: to express support for).

 

25. Mr. Sam is a dominant partner in our industry.

A. An important. B. An influential. C. An outstanding. D. A prominent

(A. more important, powerful, or successful than most or all others).

 

26. In spite of the statement credited to some government officials, we still have our misgivings about their real intentions.

A. fears. B. distrust. C. anxiety. D. objectives

(B. Distrust).

 

27. Modesty is one of our teacher’s most salient characteristics.

A. provoking. B. attractive. C. prominent. D. useful

(C. Prominent; Salient: very important or noticeable).

 

28. We all praised the student’s leaders for their intrepid stand during the crisis.

A. fearless. B. cheerful. C. reasonable. D. impressive

(A. Fearless: feeling no fear: very bold or brave). 

 

29. The chairman’s reaction was a storm in a tea cup.

A. suitable for the occasion. B. less serious than it appeared to be. C. more serious than necessary. D. greatly diminished in scope

(C. more serious than necessary). 

 

30. The recent meeting of the two rebel leaders was a propitious moment for stable government in the country.

A. delicate. B. auspicious. C. important. D. outstanding

(B. Auspicious: showing or suggesting that future success is likely).

 

31. Most people are vulnerable to communicable disease.

A. exposed. B. liable. C. open. D. immutable

(C. Open).

 

 

JAMB EXPECTED QUESTIONS

1. The witness averred that she had seen Dosun at the scene of the crime A. argued B. confirmed C. denied D. affirmed

(denied)

 

2. Tunde's reaction underscores the points I was making. A. justifies B. summarizes C. emphasizes D. clarifies

(Clarifies)

 

3. Everyone admired the manager's adroit handling of the crisis in the company A. emphasised B. skillful C. tactless D. clumsy

(skillful)

 

4. The principal took exception to the ignoble role the teacher plays d in the matter A. embarrassing B. honourable C. extraordinary D. dishonourable

(honourable)

 

5. The chairman admires incessant meetings (a) planned (b) unusual (c) irregular (d) constant

(constant)


6. The exhibition was an eye opener to all (a) dispatch (b) examination (c) style (d) display
(display)

 

7. The first round of the tournament was a doddle (a) exasperating (b) balanced (c) dodgy (d) easy

(easy)

 

8. As a journalist, Bala has always had a nose for stories (a) a command (b) cynical statement (c) soft comment (d) an instinct

(an instinct)



9. The actress screamed when she noticed an object behind her (a) wailed (b) protested (c) waded in (d) stormed out

(wailed)

10. Today's weather is favourable for a game of tennis (a) impartial (b) abnormal (c) encouraging (d) disapproving
(encouraging)


11. All the candidates looked against at the first reading of the questions (a) fulfilled (b) dismayed (c) satisfied (d) again

(dismayed)

12. I am tired of your eternal argument (a)open (b) strong (c) constant (d) useless

(Constant)
 

13. Joke gave Muhammad a jaunty smile (a) frightful (B) cheerful (c) discouraging (d) Inviting

(discouraging)

 

14. She gave a caustic remark on the occasion A. tangible B. Friendly C. Insignificant D. Sarcastic.

(Sarcastic)


15. It was a good try but it didn't quite work out. A. Come to B. come off C. come from D. come for

(come off)

 

16. Garuba’s performances in the competition was horrid. A. terrible B. encouraging C. Commendable D. rigid.

(terrible)


17. Just me the basic facts with needless details A. relevant B. extraneous C. essential D. critical

(Essential)


18. Usman likes toys made with bright and animated colours. A. dull B. sparkling C. black D. deep

(sparkling)



19. The man has strong distaste for alcohol. A. love B. aversion C. desire D. excitement.

(aversion)



20. The schism in the' organization is on the increase. A. disagreement B. understanding C. opportunity D. rot
(disagreement)


21. Sule admires people who have unbending character A. mobile B. steady C. wavering D. unstable

(steady)


22. He detests honesty A. likes B. hates C. encourages D. commands.
(hates)

 

23. The chairman admires incessant meetings. A. unusual. B. planned. C. constant. D. irregular

(constant)

 

24. Today's weather is favourable for a game of tennis.
A. impartial. B. abnormal. C. encouraging. D. disapproving

(encouraging)

25. the candidates looked aghast at the first reading of the questions.
A. fulfilled. B. dismayed. C. satisfied. D. relaxed

(dismayed)



26. Joke gave Muhammed a jaunty smile. 

A. a discouraging. B. an inviting. C. a frightful. D. a cheerful.


27. The first round of the tournament was a
doddle.
A. easy. B. balanced. C. dodgy. D. exasperating

(easy)
 

28. The lazy man cast a lustful glance at his neighbour's wife.
A. hateful. B. quick. C. covetous. D. envious

(Covetous)

29. They accused him of fomenting political unrest.
A. inciting. B. discouraging. C. preventing. D. guiding.

(inciting)

30. You can learn a great deal just from watching other players.
A. invent. B. accumulate. C. allow. D. discover.

(discover)


31. All the researchers were asked to garner information on the new viral infection.
A. collect. B disseminate. C. distort. D. give.

(collect)

32. The dispute between the two countries has resulted in the severing of diplomatic relations
A. breaking. B. securing. C. swapping. D. strengthening

(Breaking)

 

33. Ayodeji is an ardent supporter of education for the girl child.
A. an optimistic. B. a cogent. C. a passionate. D. an ignorant

(a passionate)


34. The scholars’ epitaph was demolished.
A. monument. B. embodiment. C. farmland. D. book

(monument)


35. Mohammed does his work with so much ardour.
A. enthusiasm. B. discouragement. C. knowledge. D. indifference

(enthusiasm)
 

36. The athlete is proud to be in the vanguard of sports development.
A. unforgettable position. B. leading position. C. destructive position. D. emerging position
(leading position)


37. Nwankwo was on the verge of signing a two-year contract with the club.
A. shore. B. brink. C. summit. D. height
(brink)


38. I am tired of your eternal argument
A. open. B. constant. C. strong. D. useless

(strong)

39. The lamb is a feeble little animal.
A. fat. B. quiet. C. loving. D. weak

(weak)


40. The actress screamed when she noticed an object behind her
A. wailed. B. protested. C. waded in. D. stormed out
(wailed)


41. The exhibition was an eye opener to all.
A. dispatch. B. display. C. style. D. examination

(display)

42. As a journalist, Bala has always had a nose for stories.
A. soft comment. B. cynical statement. C. an instinct. D. a command

(an instinct)

 

43. Some men will continue to cause offences until they are given a taste of their own medicine.
(a) placated (b) revenged on (c) recompensed for (d) cured
(revenged on)


44. Okibe was rusticated for his derogatory remark about the principal
(a) complimentary (b) unsavoury (c) unwarranted (d) lacklustre
(unsavoury)


45. Justice is difficult to enforce because people are unwilling to accept any loss of sovereignty.
(a) autonomy (b) position (c) leadership (d) kingdom
(autonomy)


46. There are still virtuous women in our society today.
(a) clever (b) upright (c) devilish (d) intelligent
(upright)


47. The type of response is typical of a lazy teacher.
(a) symptomatic (b) characteristic (c) universal (d) incontestable
(characteristic)


48. Akin is an inveterate gambler. (a) a selfish and self-centred (b) an extremely unlucky but popular (c) an incurable but fearful (d) a long time and incorrigible

(a long time and incorrigible)


49. He was too petrified to give the closing remarks at the conference.
(a) frightened (b) delighted (c) agitated (d) happy

(frightened)


50. During a particular time of the day, the road shimmers in the heat.
(a) darkens (b) lightens (c) shines (d) beams
(shines)


51. Every human being is vulnerable to communicable diseases.
(a) liable (b) lifted (c) immuned (d) closed
(liable)


52. Mariam looks rather furtive to Shehu.
(a) intoxicated (b) unfriendly (c) sad (d) sly
(sly)


53. The student’s union leader delivered his speech extempore.
(a) out-of-hand (b) off the cuff (c) accurately (d) courageously
(out-of-hand)


54. His story gave us an inkling of what he passed through during the strike.
(a) a possible idea (b) a taste (c) a summary (d) the right view
(a possible idea)


55. These policies have been espoused by the ruling party.
(a) condemned (b) rejected (c) supported (d) outlined
(outlined)


56. We must not foreclose reconciliation as the purpose of his trip.
(a) exclude (b) consider (c) underestimate (d) forgo
(exclude)


57. Her finding exploded widely held beliefs about learning.
(a) challenged (b) debunked (c) projected (d) confirmed
(debunked)
 

58. Since its inception in 1983, the newspaper has attracted thousands of readers.
(a) renaissance (b) coming (c) commencement (d) publication
(commencement)


59. Mrs. Asio wanted her sister to stop being so detached
(a) friendly (b) careless (c) indifferent (d) passionate
(indifferent)


60. Lantana dwelt in a ruined cottage on the hillside.
(a) sat (b) worked (c) slept (d) lived
(lived)

61. The mistake brought the show to an ignominious end
(a) a good (b) a palatable (c) a disgraceful (d) a satisfactory
(a disgraceful)


62. He compliments me on my way of doing things.
(a) complements (b) imitates (c) disgusts (d) praises
(praises)


63. The girl is angry with her friend who had ensnared her into this relationship.
(a) tricked (b) encouraged (c) encouraged (d) forced
(tricked)


64. Their new house was roofed with corrugated sheets.
(a) folded (b) iron (c) aluminium (d) corrupted
(iron)


65. The stockbroker said it was an astute move to sell the shares then.
(a) a bad (b) a shrewd (c) an unprofitable (d) an insincere
(a shrewd)


66. The principal described Oche as the most tactful person he had ever worked with.
(a) passionate (b) discrete (c) hard-working (d) innovate
(discrete)


67. The old woman is suffering from dementia.
(a) lucidity (b) senility (c) insanity (d) sagacity
(senility)


68. Some drugs have deleterious effect on a child’s development.
(a) debilitating (b) helpful (c) harmful (d) healing

(harmful)

69. Fila has always described as belligerent.
(a) beautiful (b) attractive (c) combative (d) innocent
(combative)


70. Laraba saw a forlorn little figure sitting outside the class.
(a) wise and intelligent (b) lonely and unhappy (c) smart and healthy (d) short and ugly

(lonely and unhappy)

71. The circular supersedes all previous correspondence on the matter.
(a) supports (b) displaces (c) eliminates (d) circumvent
(displaces)


72. Her problem was exacerbated by the loss of her father.
(a) exaggerated (b) solved (c) aggravated (d) infuriated
(aggravated)

 

73. A political Impasse does not offer the best opportunity for merrymaking A. manifesto B. party C. gridlock D. rally
(gridlock)


74. We were all enthusiastic as we awaited the result of the election A. bemused B. agitated C. elated D. nervous
(agitated)


75. The uniform makes the guards look absurd A. dirty B. smart C. sensible D. ridiculous

(ridiculous)


76. The law is often tardy in reacting to changing attitude A. quick B. slow C. exclusive D. generous
(slow)


77. Isa and llu ate sumptuous meal on their brother’s wedding day A. expensive B. foreign C. insipid D. cheap
(expensive)


78. Kaltume crouched over the paper on her desk A. wrote on B. stood on C. walked over D. bent over
(bent over)


79. The panacea for a country’s economic mess lies in systematic planning and hardwork A. cure B. hope C. foresight D. trouble
(cure)


80. Thousands of workers have been victims of retrenchment since the military came back to power A. Unemployment B. Trench mentality C. Suffering D. Increase in penury

(Unemployment)

81. The principal gave his speech offhand at the sports meeting A. calmly B. beautifully C. unconcerned D. unprepared
(calmly)


82. Jankoli was dressed in an old assortment of clothes A. Avalanche B. Homogeneity C. Sameness D. Melange
(Melange)


83. The girl’s father was astounded to see her appear from the shrine A. collected B. Overwhelmed C. embarrassed D. Astonished
(Astonished)


84. The director’s remark was extremely apposite to the issue being discussed A. Appropriate B. Inconsequential C. Emphatic D. Adequate
(Appropriate)


85. Her reputation is without a blemish A. Struggle B. Problem C. Fault D. Blessing
(Fault)


86. Ugo is eligible for the post of secretary A. Nominated B. Invited C. Qualified D. Intelligent
(Qualified)


87. This is an abridged version of No Longer at Ease A. An outdated B. An enlarged C. An illustrated D. A shortened
(A shortened)
